title: Arabic I
requirements: Not for students who have taken ARAB2000,2001,2050,3000 or 3050
description: As the first in a series of language courses, this course invites students without prior knowledge of Arabic to explore the basic features of Modern Standard Arabic. Supported by audiovisual aids, students will receive intensive practice in spoken and written Arabic through interactive class work, homework and online exercises. They will become familiar with the basic concepts of Arabic grammar and learn how to interact in some simple everyday situations.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to master the basic writing, reading, and communication skills such as: (1) the pronunciations, marks and writings of Arabic letters; (2) greetings in Islamic way and normal way; (3) exchanging basic personal information with someone in a social occasion; (4) describing an object, shopping, making an appointment, offering help, and describing food.
syllabus: Course Content   Unit Speech Acts Grammar Culture   1 - 3 Reading Arabic words   Short introduction to Arabic language The Arabic alphabet - isolated/ initial / medial / final The short vowels Tanween Sukon   History of Arabic Language and people Using The vowels in the History of the Arabic Language   4 - 9 Useful Expressions   The long vowels Shadda Alif Maqsura Hamza Masculine and Feminine nouns Definite article   Arabic Kitchen (Famous dishes and drinks)   10 - 13   Introduce yourself Meet someone for first time Asking about names Introduce your family     Singular demonstrative pronouns Singular personal pronouns Conjunction Singular attached pronouns   Arabic Anthology (Selected Works)   14   What do you do? Where are you from? Where do you work or study? Describing things     Interrogative particles Relative pronouns Adjectives Prepositions Simple nominal sentence in Arabic   Contributions of Arabs in World Heritage
required_readings: Ta‘allamu Al-‘arabiya (Learn Arabic Language). REFAI Amjad. Self-Published, 2016. ISBN 978-9887773900.

title: Arabic II
requirements: Prerequisite: ARAB1000;Not for students who have taken ARAB2001,2050,3000 or 3050
description: Building on the knowledge acquired in ARAB1000, this course aims to further develop students’ ability to communicate in Arabic in various everyday situations. It also seeks to give students a taste of Arabic culture and invites them to explore cultural differences. Through intensive practice students will develop more confidence in interacting in Arabic while further expanding and solidifying their understanding of the basic grammar and pronunciation patterns.

title: Arabic III
requirements: Pre-requisite: ARAB2000 or 2050;Not for students who have taken ARAB3000 or 3050
description: This course aims to further enhance students’ communication skills in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Students are expected to communicate confidently in a wider range of social interactions including more formal situations and simple professional contexts as well as reporting past events and sharing experience. At the end of this course, students will have completed a proficiency level comparable to level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).

title: Arabic I & II
requirements: Not for students who have taken ARAB1000,2000,2001,3000 or 3050
description: This is a summer intensive Arabic language course for beginners, covering the full syllabus of ARAB1000 and 2000.

title: Arabic IV
requirements: Not for students who have taken ARAB3050. Pre-requisite: ARAB2001.
description: This course aims at increasing students’ communicative fluency in oral and written Arabic. Using a variety of classroom activities and multimedia, students will build up their competence in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Through intensive practice, they will be able to communicate in a wide range of social situations with the appropriate awareness of the pragmatic rules involved. Students will receive guidance in the process of composing longer texts displaying a range of registers and styles relating to past, present and future events.

title: Arabic III & IV
requirements: Not for students who have taken ARAB2001 or 3000. Pre-requisite: ARAB2000 or 2050.
description: This is a summer intensive Arabic language course, covering the full syllabus of ARAB2001 and 3000.
